description: From Middle English troth, trothe, trouthe, trowthe, a variant of treuth, treuthe, treouthe (“allegiance, fidelity, faithfulness, loyalty; oath, pledge, promise; betrothal or marriage vow; betrothal; honour, integrity; holiness, righteousness; confidence, trust; creed, faith; fact, reality, truth”), from Old English trēowþ, trīewþ (“truth, veracity; faith, fidelity; covenant, pledge”), from Proto-Germanic *triwwiþō (“contract; promise”), equivalent to true +‎ -th. See more at truth.

definitionGroups.group: (countable, archaic) An oath, pledge, or promise.

entries.meaning: (countable, archaic) A pledge or promise to marry someone.
examples: ...I envy not the beast that takes
His license in the field of time,
Unfetter'd by the sense of crime,
To whom a conscience never wakes;
Nor, what may count itself as blest,
The heart that never plighted troth
But stagnates in the weeds of sloth;...

entries.meaning: (countable, archaic) The state of being thus pledged; betrothal, engagement.

verbs.description: troth (third-person singular simple present troths, present participle trothing, simple past and past participle trothed)
